projects.title: Momentum-based Trading Strategies in Crude Oil ETFs and Futures

associated_with.organization: Boston University, Department of Computer Science, Metropolitan College

details: Designed and backtested momentum-based trading strategies across USO (ETF) and CL=F (futures) from 2007-2024, achieving 10.6% annual returns on ETF strategies and 19.9% on futures strategies versus -8.6% for buy-and-hold baseline.

Implemented multi-window momentum analysis (Trading Day, Overnight, Open-to-Open, Close-to-Close) with both long-only and long-short strategies, identifying overnight period as critical for price discovery and signal generation.

Developed Python-based backtesting framework using pandas and numpy to evaluate 120+ strategy variations, demonstrating shorting capabilities enhance returns by 165% (from 4.0% to 10.6%) while managing drawdown risk.

Quantified risk-return characteristics across instruments: futures strategies generated 2x returns of ETF strategies but with 1.46x higher maximum drawdowns, informing risk-adjusted portfolio construction decisions.

Discovered mean-reversion effects in futures market, with contrarian strategies ranking in top 5 performers (13.6% and 11.4% annual returns), suggesting profit opportunities from time-window arbitrage.

Technical implementation: Yahoo Finance data processing, time series analysis across 4,522 trading days, performance metrics calculation, and strategy comparison framework for institutional-scale algorithmic trading deployment.

projects.title: The Silver Lining of Daily Bitcoin Trading

associated_with.organization: Boston University, Department of Computer Science, Metropolitan College

details: Engineered daily trading strategy leveraging overnight silver price movements to predict 24-hour Bitcoin close-to-close returns, achieving 68.65% average annual returns over 10 years versus 58.69% buy-and-hold baseline.

Implemented cross-asset signal generation: positive overnight silver returns trigger Bitcoin long positions; non-positive returns trigger cash positions, requiring only OHLC data and minimal computational overhead for retail investor implementation.

Backtested strategy across 2014-2024 market cycles (3,652 trading days) with key finding: strategy sacrifices 16.4% upside in bull markets (avg 68.65% vs 58.69%) but reduces downside by 50% in bear markets and provides significant drawdown mitigation.

Quantified risk-adjusted performance: maximum drawdowns reduced from average 51.2% (buy-and-hold) to 33.8% (strategy), demonstrating 34% lower volatility while maintaining competitive returns during market downturns.

$100 initial investment analysis: buy-and-hold grew to $11,589.68; strategy grew to $23,048.77 (99% higher 10-year return), showing superior long-term compounding despite lower annual returns in bull years.

Identified distinct performance regimes: strategy outperforms 40% of years (negative return years: 2014, 2018, 2022 where losses contained to -17.84% to -47.70% vs -61.00% to -72.41%), demonstrating defensive properties and non-correlated silver relationship for portfolio diversification.

projects.title: Estimating the Accuracy of a Bagged Ensemble

associated_with.organization: Boston University, Department of Computer Science, Metropolitan College

details: Developed probabilistic framework to predict ensemble accuracy for bagged classifiers using Bernoulli distributions and majority voting theory, enabling data scientists to determine optimal ensemble size without exhaustive trial-and-error experimentation.

Derived mathematical formulations based on Condorcet's Jury Theorem for ensemble voting dynamics, proving ensemble outperforms individual learners only when weak learner accuracy exceeds 50% threshold.

Implemented three statistical approximation approaches (Poisson, Normal, and Binomial distributions) for finite ensemble accuracy prediction, achieving 2.22% mean absolute relative error using ensemble averaging method.

Extended framework from identical weak learners to heterogeneous classifiers using Poisson-Binomial distribution theory, enabling practical application to real-world random forests and bagging algorithms with varying individual accuracies.

Validated methodology on Iris dataset with Random Forest ensembles (depth=1), demonstrating prediction accuracy within 7.5% mean relative error across ensemble sizes 11-51, supporting scalable ensemble sizing decisions.

Technical implementation: Python-based statistical modeling with gamma function analysis, incomplete gamma function computation, Central Limit Theorem applications, and accuracy prediction formulas for institutional algorithmic training.
